par.text: Calcium was discovered in 1808 by the English chemist Humphry Davy. Its name is derived from the Latin word

- lime. Calcium is a fairly soft, silvery-grey metal, malleable and ductile. Its ions impart a brick-red colour to a flame. Due to its high reactivity, calcium has to be stored in kerosene. On contact with air calcium oxidises to calcium oxide -CaO, even at room temperature. The metal reacts with water to form calcium hydroxide and hydrogen; with acids - to produce salts and hydrogen. At elevated temperatures calcium also reacts with nitrogen and the halogens.
